coredata.dc:title: Discovery of 7H-pyrrolo[2,3-d]pyrimidine derivatives as selective covalent irreversible inhibitors of interleukin-2-inducible T-cell kinase (Itk)

All rights reserved.Elsevier Masson SAS.Tang, GuanghuiLiu, LihongWang, XueyingPan, Zhengying Interleukin-2-inducible T-cell kinase (Itk) plays an important role in multiple signal transduction pathways in T and mast cells, and is a potential drug target for treating inflammatory diseases, autoimmune diseases, and T cell leukemia/lymphoma. Herein, we describe the discovery of a series of covalent Itk inhibitors based on the 7H-pyrrolo[2,3-d]pyrimidine scaffold. Placing an appropriate substitution group at a hydration site of the ATP binding pocket of Itk and using a saturated heterocyclic ring as a linker to the reactive group were crucial for selectivity. The optimized compound 9 showed potent activity against Itk, excellent selectivity for Itk over Btk and other structurally related kinases, inhibition of phospholipase C-γ1 (PLC-γ1) phosphorylation in cells, and anti-proliferative effects against multiple T leukemia/lymphoma cell lines. Compound 9 can serve as a valuable compound for further determination of functions of Itk. 0falsefalse7H-pyrrolo[2,3-d]pyrimidineItkCovalent inhibitorSelectivity

Detailed view of the pyridyl groups of the two compounds. (c). Structures of compound 15 and literature compound 7a. (c) (i) 4-morpholinoaniline, Pd2(dba)3, Xantphos, NaO-tBu, toluene, microwave, 145 °C, 90 min. (ii) TFA/DCM, 4 h, EtOH/H2O, K2CO3, 1 h, 19% for two steps. head.ce:title: Discovery of 7H-pyrrolo[2,3-d]pyrimidine derivatives as selective covalent irreversible inhibitors of interleukin-2-inducible T-cell kinase (Itk)

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: State Key Laboratory of Chemical Oncogenomics, Engineering Laboratory for Chiral Drug Synthesis, School of Chemical Biology and Biotechnology, Shenzhen Graduate School, Peking University, Shenzhen, 518055, China

sa:affiliation.sa:organization: State Key Laboratory of Chemical Oncogenomics
Engineering Laboratory for Chiral Drug Synthesis
School of Chemical Biology and Biotechnology

ce:correspondence.ce:text: Corresponding author. Xili University Town, Peking University Campus, F-311, Shenzhen, 518055, China.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Interleukin-2-inducible T-cell kinase (Itk) plays an important role in multiple signal transduction pathways in T and mast cells, and is a potential drug target for treating inflammatory diseases, autoimmune diseases, and T cell leukemia/lymphoma. Herein, we describe the discovery of a series of covalent Itk inhibitors based on the 7H-pyrrolo[2,3-d]pyrimidine scaffold. Placing an appropriate substitution group at a hydration site of the ATP binding pocket of Itk and using a saturated heterocyclic ring as a linker to the reactive group were crucial for selectivity. The optimized compound 9 showed potent activity against Itk, excellent selectivity for Itk over Btk and other structurally related kinases, inhibition of phospholipase C-γ1 (PLC-γ1) phosphorylation in cells, and anti-proliferative effects against multiple T leukemia/lymphoma cell lines. Compound 9 can serve as a valuable compound for further determination of functions of Itk.

ce:section.ce:para: Interleukin-2-inducible T-cell kinase (Itk) is a non-receptor tyrosine kinase within the Tec kinase family, which also includes Bruton's tyrosine kinase (Btk), Tec, Bmx, and Rlk. Itk is mainly expressed in T cells, natural killer cells, and mast cells, and plays a significant role in the T cell receptor (TCR) signaling pathway [1–3]. Activation of the TCR signaling pathway leads to phosphorylation of Tyr512 of Itk, followed by auto-phosphorylation of Tyr180, resulting in full activation of Itk. Activated Itk phosphorylates PLC-γ1, which transduces the signal downstream [4,5].

Itk knock-out (ITK−/-) mice showed a deficiency of T helper 2 (Th 2) cells [6]. Deletion of Itk led to reduction of TCR induced proliferation and secretion of several cytokines including IL-2, IL-4, IL-5, IL-10, and IFN-γ [7]. ITK−/- mice showed resistance to ovalbumin-induced asthma [8,9], and reduced inflammatory symptoms [10]. Itk deficiency also affected the balance between T helper 17 (Th17) cells and T regulatory (Treg) cells [11], and Itk knock-out (ITK−/-) cells also showed decreased expression level of IL-17A [12], a drug target for the treatment of psoriasis [13]. Recently, several reports indicated that Itk may be a potential drug target for the treatment of T cell leukemia/lymphoma [14–16].

A number of Itk inhibitors have been developed (Fig. 1 ) [17]. BMS-488516 was the first reported inhibitor to specifically target Itk, and it showed good potency but poor pharmacokinetic properties [18]. Compounds 2 and 3 showed excellent selectivity for kinases related to the TCR pathway [19,20]. JTE-051 (a derivative of compound 4) was the only reported Itk inhibitor that progressed to clinical research, and was evaluated for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis by Japan Tobacco [21]. Compound 5 was reported as an allosteric inhibitor. Three covalent inhibitors of Itk (compounds 6–8) were developed to target the Cys442 residue in the ATP binding pocket of Itk, which is similar to the Cys481 of Btk [22–24]. However, compounds 6 and 7 also potently inhibited Btk, and compound 8 was a dual inhibitor of Itk and Rlk.

The low Km (ATP) of Itk (5 μM) provides a challenge to maintenance of inhibitory activity when using reversible inhibitors in a cellular environment where the ATP concentration is 1–2 mM [25]. Covalent inhibitors can be used to obtain high potency and selectivity, allowing for effective competition with natural substrates of kinases.

Herein, we reported the discovery of a series of novel covalent inhibitors based on the 7H-pyrrolo[2,3-d]pyrimidine scaffold. The optimized compound 9 demonstrated good potency and excellent selectivity for Itk compared to Btk, suggesting that this compound may serve as a useful tool for studying Itk functions.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Core scaffold design and study of structure and activity relationships (SAR)
ce:section.ce:para: Covalent kinase inhibitors follow a two-step process to engage with target proteins. The first step is a reversible binding step with the kinase, and the second is formation of a covalent bond with a reactive amino acid residue in the protein. Our strategy to develop covalent inhibitors initiated with optimization of reversible interactions between compounds and the kinase to obtain selective non-covalent inhibitors with good potency. Then, a reactive group was added at the appropriate position to allow the inhibitors to form covalent interactions.

Compound 10 (AC0010) was an irreversible inhibitor of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) T790M mutant, and is currently being evaluated in clinical studies for treatment of patients with non–small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) [26]. Compound 10 had single-digit nM activity against EGFR, showed greater than 80% inhibition against Itk at 1 μM, and exhibited similar potency against Btk and other Tec family kinases [27]. Therefore, we used this 7H-pyrrolo[2,3-d]pyrimidine scaffold as the starting point and engineered the molecule to remove activities against other kinases, particularly EGFR and Btk, to obtain selective covalent inhibitors for Itk. We docked the basic scaffold 11 into the Itk kinase domain (PDB: 3qgw). Compound 11 formed three hydrogen bonds with the main chain of Glu436 and Met438 in the hinge region (Fig. 2 b), and the docking structure suggested that the selectivity and activity may be tuned through optimization of groups at three positions: R1, a group extending from the phenyl ring would be exposed to the solvent area and may be used to introduce hydrophilic groups; R2, a reactive group could be installed at the C4 position through an appropriate linker; and R3, a group originating from the C5 position points toward a pocket inside the kinase and may provide increased selectivity.

To quickly assess the feasibility of our design, we altered 11 as follows: a morpholinyl group was added at the R1 position, a phenoxyl group was added as a potential linker of the reactive group at the R2 position, and aromatic groups were added at the R3 position (Table 1 ). Compound 12, which had a phenyl group at the R3 position, showed weak activity (2.1 μM) against Itk and addition of an amino or a methoxy group (compounds 13–14) at the para position of the phenyl group further reduced inhibitory activity. However, replacement of the phenyl group with a pyridyl group (compounds 15–18) greatly improved the potency. Compound 15 had an IC50 of 14 nM, but potency decreased when a methyl group was added at the ortho position of the N atom (compound 18). Then, we introduced an amino or propanamide group at the R2 position. Compounds 19 and 20 had similar potency to 15, which suggested tolerability for modifications at this position. Compound 21 was then synthesized by addition of an acrylamide reactive group, which resulted in an IC50 of 0.5 nM for Itk. However, compound 21 showed poor selectivity among kinases with a reactive cysteine similar to Cys442 of Itk (Table S1), as evidenced by an IC50 of 3.9 nM against Btk. Thus, more optimization was necessary.

We more closely examined the R3 site to identify specific interactions with Itk to improve selectivity through noncovalent binding. The Itk inhibitor 2 developed by Vertex showed excellent selectivity [19], which was attributed to replacement of a hydration site in Itk. This hydration site was unique to Itk and was estimated to be highly thermodynamically unfavorable [19,28]. Displacement of the hydration site with an sp2-nitrogen could significantly improve the selectivity of inhibitors [29]. We compared the binding mode of compound 15 with the literature reported inhibitor 7a (Fig. 3 ) [19] and found that the two compounds formed similar key hydrogen bonds with the backbone of Met 438, and that the positions of the pyridyl groups, which served as the replacement at the hydration site, were very close (Fig. 3b).

The docking model in Fig. 3 suggested that incorporation of an amino group at the meta-position of the phenyl ring could result in formation of a hydrogen bond with Glu406. Compared to compound 13, compound 22 showed improved potency (Table 2 ), while compound 23 modified with a methylamino group further increased potency. However, the dimethylamino compound 24 showed greatly decreased potency, suggesting that compound 23 may form a hydrogen bond with Glu406 and act as a hydrogen bond donor.

The phenyl group was replaced with a pyridinyl group to produce compounds 25–27. Compound 27 was a potent inhibitor (IC50 = 4.8 nM), which may have resulted from hydrogen bonding with the conserved residue Lys391. Addition of a pyrazinyl group was well-tolerated, resulting in an IC50 of 23 nM for compound 28.

Using compound 28 as the reference compound, we also examined the R1 position, which is the solvent-exposed area. Different hydrophilic groups were incorporated to yield compounds 29–32, which exhibited good potency. Addition of an acetylated piperazinyl group (compound 30) led to much better potency. However, further derivatization with a covalent reactive group, which resulted in compound 33, failed to achieve selectivity for Itk over Btk (Table 2).

Analysis of the selectivity data for compounds 30 (Table S1) and 33 showed that introduction of a reactive group significantly increased inhibitory activity of 33 for Btk even though noncovalent compound 30 showed excellent selectivity against Btk. Thus, the reactive group region (R2) was further explored to seek a balance between reactivity and selectivity. Since good selectivity for Itk over Btk was already obtained with noncovalent compounds, we replaced the phenyl group with saturated rings, which would lead to a weaker reactive group [30]. Compound 34, which contained a cyclohexyl group, and compound 35, which contained a pyranyl group, had IC50 values of 5.1 nM and 7.1 nM, respectively, and had good selectivity for Itk over Btk, Janus kinase 3 (Jak3), and EGFR, demonstrating that saturated rings were well-tolerated (Table 3 ). We then introduced a classic acrylamide reactive group onto the heterocyclic rings. Compounds 36 and 37 were potent Itk inhibitors, with the (R)-enantiomer (37) showing slightly better potency. A more dramatic difference was observed between compounds 38 and 39, which contained a six-membered ring. The (S)-enantiomer 38 significantly lost inhibitory activity against Itk, while the (R)-enantiomer, compound 39, retained good potency and selectivity for Itk against Btk, Jak3, and EGFR kinases.

The hydrophilic group at the R1 position also influenced potency and selectivity. Compound 40, modified with an N-ethylpiperazinyl moiety, exhibited much lower selectivity. Compound 41, modified with a morpholinyl group, exhibited excellent potency and maintained relatively good selectivity. Adjusting the orientation of the reactive group led to compounds 9 and 42, which showed decent potency and excellent selectivity. Changing the pyrazinyl ring to a pyridinyl ring at the R3 position (compounds 43, 44 and 45) did not result in better inhibition. Compound 45, modified with a 3-(methylamino)pyridin-4-yl group, lost selectivity for Itk over Btk and other kinases, which was likely due to hydrogen bond formation between the nitrogen atom on the pyridyl ring and a conserved Lys391 residue. Compound 46, which was later used as a labeling probe for Itk, showed decreased inhibitory activity (IC50 = 55 nM) against Itk and was equally potent against Jak3.

Compound 9 was a potent Itk inhibitor, exhibiting 33-fold greater selectivity for Itk than for Jak3, and over 250-fold greater selectivity for Itk compared to Btk and EGFR. Based on these results, compound 9 was selected for further evaluation. Compound 9 was assessed against a panel of 30 kinases at 0.4 μM (100-fold of its IC50 against Itk): 9 was inactive against most of the kinases tested while showing greater than 80% inhibition of Tak1, Itk, Flt3, Blk, Lck, Abl, Jak3, and IRAK4 (Fig. 4 , Table S2). Further testing showed that the IC50 of 9 was 54 nM for Tak1, 74 nM for Lck, and 198 nM for Blk. Tak1, Flt3, Lck, Abl, and IRAK4 do not contain a cysteine homologous to Cys442 found in Itk. As such, compound 9 could not form a similar covalent interaction with these kinases as it could with Itk.

We obtained kinetic binding data for compounds 9, 39, and 41 (Table 4 ). Compounds 9 and 41 showed lower K i values, indicating better noncovalent interactions than compound 39. Furthermore, the much lower k inact value of compound 9 suggested a slower reaction. Therefore, adjustment of noncovalent interactions and reactivity can provide a balance between potency and selectivity of covalent inhibitors.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Compound 9 potently inhibited Itk activity in live cells and growth of multiple T cell lymphoma cell lines
ce:section.ce:para: To examine the ability of the synthesized compounds to inhibit TCR-induced activation in live cells, we tested compounds 39, 41, and 9 in Jurkat cells, a T cell leukemia cell line. Jurkat cells were treated with compounds and then stimulated with anti-CD3/CD28 beads for 30 min to activate the TCR signaling pathway. Immunoblot analysis showed that each of the three compounds (39, 41 and 9) inhibited phosphorylation of PLC-γ1, a direct physiological substrate of Itk. Compound 41 was the most potent, and 39 was the least potent (Fig. 6a). Consistent with enzymatic assay data, compound 9 showed almost no inhibitory effect on the phosphorylation level of the Btk substrate, PLC-γ2, in Ramos cells, a B cell line that expresses Btk but not Itk (Table S2). Probe 46 labeled Itk in Jurkat cells, and this labeling was completely blocked by the covalent inhibitors 9 and PRN694, but not excess BMS509744, a noncovalent Itk inhibitor (Fig. 6b).

We docked compound 9 into the ATP binding pocket of Itk (PDB code: 3qgw). Compound 9 formed three H-bonds with the hinge region in a manner similar to compound 11. As expected, the methylamino group of 9 formed a hydrogen bond with Glu406. The distance between the terminal carbon atom of the acrylamide group and the sulfur atom of Cys442 was 4.9 Å, making it possible to form a covalent bond through a Michael addition reaction. The morpholinyl group was pointed toward the solvent region. Fig. 8 b summarizes all potential noncovalent interactions between the inhibitor and the binding pocket.

The representative synthetic routes of each of the compounds are described below (Schemes 1–3
) [33,34]. Synthesis was started by protecting the N-H group with a trimethylsilylethoxymethyl (SEM) protecting group. Different substitution groups were introduced at the R1, R2, and R3 positions. First, a linker to the reactive group at R2 was inserted through an SNAr displacement reaction in the presence of K2CO3, resulting in compounds S2 or S5. Compound S7 was synthesized via an SNAr displacement reaction using potassium tert-butoxide as a base. A phenyl group was introduced at R3 via a Suzuki-Miyaura coupling reaction catalyzed by Pd(dppf)Cl2 to produce compound S3. Compounds S4, S6, and S8 were synthesized through a two-step process including a Miyaura boration reaction followed by a Suzuki coupling. Finally, different hydrophilic groups at R1 were added to the scaffold by a Buchwald-Hartwig cross-coupling reaction using various palladium catalysts. To synthesize compounds 12 and 28, a deprotection step to remove the Boc group and SEM group was performed with TFA followed by addition of K2CO3. For covalent inhibitors, the deprotected intermediates were reacted with acryloyl chloride to produce compounds 9 and 33 using N,N-diisopropyl-ethylamine or saturated sodium carbonate aqueous solution as a base, respectively.

In summary, a series of novel covalent irreversible inhibitors of Itk based on the 7H-pyrrolo[2,3-d]pyrimidine scaffold were identified through a stepwise structure-activity relationship study. Optimizations of both noncovalent interactions and covalent reactive groups were required to reach a balance between potency and selectivity of the inhibitors. The optimized compound 9 demonstrated potent activity against Itk and excellent selectivity for Itk over Btk. Compound 9 also exerted a potent inhibitory effect on phosphorylation of PLC-γ1 by Itk in Jurkat cells, and showed promising anti-proliferative effects on several T cell leukemia and lymphoma cell lines. Compound 9 is a valuable tool to study the functions of Itk in complex biological systems. Further improvement of this series of inhibitors will be reported in due course.

All reagents were purchased commercially and used without further purification or distillation, unless otherwise stated. Reactions were monitored by thin-layer chromatography (TLC) carried out on 0.25 mm Yantai silica gel plates (HSGF254) using UV light as visualizing agent. Flash column chromatography was carried out using Yantai silica gel (ZCX-II, particle size 0.048–0.075 mm). 1H-NMR and 13C-NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Advance 400 (1H: 400 MHz, 13C: 101 MHz) or Bruker Advance 500 (1H: 500 MHz, 13C: 126 MHz) spectrometer at ambient temperature. High resolution accurate mass spectrometry determinations (HRMS) for all final target compounds were obtained on a Bruker Apex IV RTMS. Purity of compounds was determined by HPLC chromatograms acquired on an Agilent 1200 HPLC or 1260 HPLC. Analyses were conducted by an Agilent PN990967-202 Eclipse XDB-C18 250 mm × 9.4 mm column, using a water–MeCN gradient. Detection was conducted at 254 nm, and the average peak area was used to determine purity. All of the compounds had a purity ≥95%.

Step 1: To a flask containing compound S1 (2.5 g, 8 mmol), SEM-Cl (1.5 mL, 8.4 mmol, 90% purity), and 50 mL THF stirring at 0 °C, NaH (1.28 g, 32 mmol, 60% purity) was added, and the mixture was stirred for 0.5 h. The reaction was quenched with saturated NH4Cl solution and concentrated under vacuum. The dried residue was diluted with brine and extracted with ethyl acetate three times. The combined organic layers were dried with anhydrous sodium sulfate and filtered. The solvent was removed under reduced pressure. The crude product was purified by silica flash chromatography to yield SEM-protected product (3.0 g, 85%). The product (1.0 g, 2.27 mmol), phenol (0.21 g, 2.27 mmol), and K2CO3 (0.626 g, 4.54 mmol) were dissolved in 20 mL MeCN, and the reaction was stirred and heated at 85 °C overnight. After cooling, the solution was concentrated under vacuum and the residue was diluted with brine and extracted with ethyl acetate three times. The combined organic layers were dried with anhydrous sodium sulfate and filtered. The solvent was removed under reduced pressure. The residue was purified by silica flash chromatography to isolate compound S2 (1.0 g, 88%). 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.44 (t, J = 7.9 Hz, 2H), 7.36 (s, 1H), 7.33 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 2H), 7.27 (t, J = 7.3 Hz, 1H), 5.55 (s, 2H), 3.66–3.51 (m, 2H), 1.03–0.90 (m, 2H), 0.00 (s, 9H).13C NMR (126 MHz, CDCl3) δ 161.26, 152.91, 151.89, 151.12, 130.87, 128.55, 124.74, 120.60, 105.30, 76.16, 72.18, 65.96, 16.73, −2.34. .MS (ESI) m/z 502 (M+H)+.

Step 2: S2 (1.0 g, 2 mmol), phenylboronic acid (0.24 g, 2 mmol), Pd(dppf)Cl2 (0.293 g, 0.4 mmol), K2CO3 (0.552 g, 4 mmol), 20 mL 1,2-dimethoxy-ethane, and 5 mL of water were added to a flask. The reaction was stirred and heated to reflux for 1 h. After cooling, the solution was concentrated under vacuum and the residue was diluted with brine and extracted with ethyl acetate three times. The combined organic layers were dried with anhydrous sodium sulfate and filtered. The solvent was removed under reduced pressure. The residue was purified by silica flash chromatography to yield S3 (0.3 g, 33%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.79–7.73 (m, 2H), 7.44 (t, J = 7.8 Hz, 4H), 7.39 (s, 1H), 7.36 (d, J = 7.4 Hz, 1H), 7.31–7.26 (m, 3H), 5.68 (s, 2H), 3.71–3.62 (m, 2H), 1.06–0.98 (m, 2H), 0.04 (s, 10H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, CDCl3) δ 164.09, 156.14, 153.92, 153.69, 134.59, 130.92, 130.22, 129.79, 128.52, 126.94, 126.09, 122.93, 119.77, 103.94, 74.59, 68.26, 19.17, 0.05. MS (ESI) m/z 452 (M+H)+.
Compounds 13–18 and 22 were synthesized with the same procedures as for 12, the synthetic procedures of compounds 19–21, 23–24 were supplied in the supplementary data.

Step 1: A flask containing S2 (2.0 g, 4 mmol), 4,4,5,5-tetramethyl-1,3,2-dioxaborolane (1.16 mL, 4 mmol), Pd2(dba)3 (0.732 g, 0.8 mmol), XPhos (0.572 g, 1.2 mmol), triethylamine (2.2 mL, 16 mmol), and 40 mL of 1,4-dioxane was stirred at 95 °C for 12 h. After cooling, the solution was filtered using diatomite, concentrated under vacuum, and the residue was diluted with brine and extracted with ethyl acetate three times. The combined organic layers were dried with anhydrous sodium sulfate and filtered. The solvent was removed under reduced pressure and the residue was purified by silica flash chromatography to obtain crude product (1.5 g, yield ∼75%). The crude product (0.133 g, 0.26 mmol), tert-butyl (6-bromopyrazin-2-yl)(methyl)carbamate (0.076 g, 0.26 mmol), Pd(PPh3)4 (0.06 g, 0.052 mmol), Na2CO3 (0.082 g, 0.78 mmol), 3 mL of 1,4-dioxane, and 0.6 mL of water were added to a microwave tube and sealed. The microwave tube was heated in a microwave reactor at 120 °C for 25 min. After cooling, the solution was filtered using diatomite, concentrated under vacuum, and the residue was diluted with brine and extracted with ethyl acetate three times. The combined organic layers were dried with anhydrous sodium sulfate and filtered. The solvent was removed under reduced pressure and the residue was purified by silica flash chromatography to yield S4 (0.116 g, 76%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 9.02 (s, 1H), 8.97 (s, 1H), 7.93 (s, 1H), 7.43 (t, J = 7.9 Hz, 2H), 7.25 (dd, J = 5.5, 4.5 Hz, 3H), 5.66 (s, 2H), 3.65–3.59 (m, 2H), 3.45 (s, 3H), 1.55 (s, 9H), 1.00–0.94 (m, 2H), −0.01 (s, 9H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, CDCl3) δ 163.92, 156.52, 155.17, 154.33, 153.39, 152.12, 145.77, 139.86, 138.53, 131.02, 129.87, 127.25, 122.99, 115.84, 103.10, 83.54, 74.77, 68.41, 34.89, 29.66, 19.09, −0.00. MS (ESI) m/z 583 (M+H)+.
Compounds 25–27, 29–32 were synthesized with the same procedures as for 28.

Step 1: S5 was synthesized through a procedure similar to S3. Then, S5 (2.0 g, 3.2 mmol), bis(pinacolato)diborane (1.64 g, 6.4 mmol), Pd(PPh3)2Cl2 (0.27 g, 0.38 mmol), and potassium acetate (1.9 g, 19.3 mmol) were dissolved in 30 mL of DMF, heated to 75 °C, and stirred overnight. After cooling, the mixture was filtered using diatomite, dissolved in ethyl acetate, washed with brine three times, dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated. The residue was purified by silica flash chromatography to yield the intermediate product (0.91 g, 46%). The intermediate (0.91 g, 1.45 mmol), tert-butyl (6-bromopyrazin-2-yl)(methyl)carbamate (0.29 g, 1 mmol), Pd(PPh3)4 (0.254 g, 0.22 mmol), Na2CO3 (0.46 g, 4.35 mmol), 15 mL of 1,4-dioxane, and 3 mL of water were added to a microwave tube, sealed, stirred, and heated to 120 °C for 25 min. After cooling, the mixture was filtered using diatomite, concentrated under vacuum, and the residue was diluted with brine and extracted with ethyl acetate three times. The combined organic layers were dried with anhydrous sodium sulfate and filtered. The solvent was removed under reduced pressure, and the residue was purified by silica flash chromatography to yield S6 (0.38 g, 63%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 8.99 (s, 1H), 8.95 (s, 1H), 7.92 (s, 1H), 7.48 (s, 1H), 7.30 (dd, J = 14.2, 6.1 Hz, 1H), 7.11 (dd, J = 8.2, 1.3 Hz, 1H), 6.94–6.85 (m, 1H), 6.82 (s, 1H), 5.68 (s, 2H), 3.68–3.57 (m, 2H), 3.46 (s, 3H), 1.56 (s, 9H), 1.48 (s, 9H), 1.03–0.93 (m, 2H), −0.00 (s, 9H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, CDCl3) δ 164.04, 156.47, 155.21, 154.38, 153.86, 152.14, 145.80, 141.35, 139.90, 138.55, 131.12, 129.77, 117.26, 115.90, 113.12, 103.14, 83.56, 82.03, 74.80, 68.45, 34.96, 32.96, 29.68, 24.03, 19.12, 15.50, −0.00. MS (ESI) m/z 698 (M+H)+.

Step 2: S6 (1.0 g, 1.43 mmol), 1-(4-(4-aminophenyl)piperazin-1-yl)ethan-1-one (0.47 g, 2.14 mmol), Pd2(dba)3 (0.042 g, 0.046 mmol), PXantPhos-Pd-G2 (0.12 g, 0.143 mmol), NaO-tBu (0.41 g, 4.29 mmol), and 10 mL of toluene were added to a microwave tube and sealed, and the mixture was heated at 145 °C for 1 h in an oil bath. After cooling, the solution was filtered using diatomite, concentrated under vacuum, and the residue was diluted with brine and extracted with ethyl acetate three times. The combined organic layers were dried with anhydrous sodium sulfate and filtered. The solvent was removed under reduced pressure and the residue was purified by silica flash chromatography to yield an intermediate product, which was dissolved in 7 mL of dichloromethane and 7 mL of TFA, then stirred for 4 h at room temperature. The reaction solution was concentrated under vacuum and dissolved in 10 mL of ethyl alcohol, to which 5 drops of water and K2CO3 (0.99 g, 7.15 mmol) were added, and the reaction was stirred for 1 h. The reaction mixture was filtered and concentrated under vacuum. The residue was purified by silica flash chromatography to yield the deprotected compound (0.155 g, ∼20%). The deprotected compound (0.045 g, 0.08 mmol) was dissolved in 5 mL of THF and stirred at 0 °C, 0.5 mL water, and Na2CO3 (0.17 g, 1.6 mmol) were added to the reaction, followed by addition of acryloyl chloride (10 μL, 0.12 mmol), and stirred at 0 °C for 10 min. The solution was concentrated under vacuum and the residue was purified by silica flash chromatography to yield compound 33 (0.0045 g, 9% for the last three steps). 1H NMR (400 MHz, MeOD) δ 8.46 (s, 1H), 7.72 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 1H), 7.67 (d, J = 7.6 Hz, 2H), 7.60 (s, 1H), 7.45 (t, J = 8.2 Hz, 1H), 7.37 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 2H), 7.03 (dd, J = 8.1, 1.5 Hz, 1H), 6.78 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 2H), 6.47–6.40 (m, 1H), 6.39 (d, J = 2.4 Hz, 1H), 5.78 (dd, J = 9.5, 2.4 Hz, 1H), 4.59 (s, 2H), 3.79–3.62 (m, 5H), 3.03 (d, J = 21.7 Hz, 4H), 2.97 (s, 3H), 2.79 (s, 1H), 2.15 (s, 3H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, DMSO‑d 6) δ 170.03, 165.14, 163.96, 158.33, 157.17, 156.49, 154.99, 147.31, 147.10, 142.13, 138.00, 135.81, 133.58, 131.68, 130.90, 129.06, 121.32, 120.25, 118.98, 118.32, 115.52, 97.50, 56.76, 51.74, 51.30, 50.46, 47.47, 42.62, 29.01, 23.04. HRMS (m/z) calcd. for C32H33N10O3 ([M+H]+) 605.2737; found 605.2732.

Step 1: SEM-protected S1 (2.0 g, 4.53 mmol) and tert-butyl 4-hydroxypiperidine-1-carboxylate (0.912 g, 4.53 mmol) were dissolved in 30 mL of 1,4-dioxane and stirred at 0 °C. Then, 6.8 mL of 1M KO-tBu in THF was added to the reaction and stirred at 0 °C for 15 min. The reaction was quenched with saturated NH4Cl solution and concentrated under vacuum. The residue was diluted with brine and extracted with ethyl acetate three times. The combined organic layers were dried with anhydrous sodium sulfate and filtered. The solvent was removed under reduced pressure and the residue was purified by silica flash chromatography to yield product S7 (2.0 g, 73%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.24 (s, 1H), 5.62 (d, J = 3.5 Hz, 1H), 5.48 (s, 2H), 3.63 (dd, J = 7.9, 4.3 Hz, 4H), 3.54–3.42 (m, 2H), 1.99–1.81 (m, 4H), 1.45 (s, 9H), 0.93–0.85 (m, 2H), −0.06 (s, 9H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, CDCl3) δ 163.64, 156.15, 154.47, 132.25, 107.40, 80.95, 74.36, 72.93, 68.16, 52.57, 31.56, 29.85, 19.01, −0.04. MS (ESI) m/z 609 (M+H)+.

Step 2: S7 (2.38 g, 3.9 mmol), bis(pinacolato)diborane (3.0 g, 11.7 mmol), Pd(PPh3)2Cl2 (0.41 g, 0.585 mmol), and potassium acetate (1.5 g, 15.6 mmol) were dissolved in 30 mL of DMF, heated to 75 °C, and stirred overnight. After cooling, the mixture was filtered using diatomite, dissolved in ethyl acetate, and washed with brine three times. The organic layer was dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated. The residue was purified by silica flash chromatography to yield an intermediate product (1.26 g, 52%). The intermediate product (1.26 g, 2.06 mmol), tert-butyl (6-bromopyrazin-2-yl)(methyl)carbamate (0.42 g, 1.44 mmol), Pd(PPh3)4 (0.206 g, 0.37 mmol), Na2CO3 (0.655 g, 6.18 mmol), 15 mL of 1,4-dioxane, and 2.5 mL of water were added to a microwave tube, sealed, stirred, and heated to 120 °C in a microwave reactor for 20 min. After cooling, the solution was concentrated under vacuum and the residue was diluted with brine and extracted with ethyl acetate three times. The combined organic layers were dried with anhydrous sodium sulfate and filtered. The organic solvent was concentrated, and the residue was purified by silica flash chromatography to yield S8 (0.62 g, 62%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 8.91 (d, J = 2.7 Hz, 2H), 7.81 (s, 1H), 5.60 (s, 2H), 5.58–5.49 (m, 1H), 3.73 (d, J = 13.1, 6.1, 4.0 Hz, 2H), 3.63–3.52 (m, 2H), 3.43 (s, 3H), 3.39–3.24 (m, 2H), 2.09 (d, J = 18.5 Hz, 2H), 1.85 (dt, J = 12.7, 4.2 Hz, 2H), 1.54 (s, 9H), 1.44 (s, 9H), 0.97–0.86 (m, 2H), −0.06 (s, 9H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, CDCl3) δ 163.79, 155.85, 155.14, 154.30, 152.09, 145.78, 139.73, 138.79, 129.12, 115.81, 102.80, 83.56, 81.05, 74.88, 74.64, 68.28, 34.87, 31.98, 29.72, 19.03, −0.06. MS (ESI) m/z 690 (M+H)+.

Step 3: S8 (0.5 g, 0.72 mmol), 4-morpholinoaniline (0.26 g, 1.44 mmol), PXantPhos-Pd-G2 (0.064 g, 0.072 mmol), NaO-tBu (0.2 g, 2.16 mmol), and 12 mL of toluene were added to a microwave tube and sealed. The mixture was heated at 145 °C for 1 h in an oil bath. After cooling, the solution was filtered using diatomite and concentrated under vacuum, and the residue was diluted with brine and extracted with ethyl acetate three times. The combined organic layers were dried with anhydrous sodium sulfate and filtered. The solvent was removed under reduced pressure and the residue was purified by silica flash chromatography to yield an intermediate product. Then, the intermediate product was dissolved in 8 mL of dichloromethane and 8 mL TFA, and stirred for 4 h at room temperature. The solution was concentrated under vacuum and dissolved in 10 mL of ethyl alcohol and 5 drops of water. K2CO3 (0.5 g, 3.6 mmol) was added and the reaction was stirred for 1 h. The reaction mixture was filtered and concentrated under vacuum. The residue was purified by silica flash chromatography to yield a deprotected amino compound (0.107 g, 21%). Then, the deprotected compound (0.107 g, 0.21 mmol) was dissolved in 5 mL of THF and stirred at 0 °C. Five drops of water and N,N-diisopropyl-ethylamine (0.1 mL, 0.63 mmol) were added to the reaction, followed by acryloyl chloride (16 μL, 0.2 mmol). The reaction was stirred at 0 °C for 10 min. The solution was concentrated under vacuum and the residue was purified by silica flash chromatography to yield compound 9 (0.013 g, 3% for the last three steps). 1H NMR (400 MHz, MeOD) δ 8.36 (s, 1H), 7.63 (s, 1H), 7.53 (d, J = 8.9 Hz, 2H), 7.47 (s, 1H), 6.86 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 2H), 6.73 (dd, J = 16.8, 10.7 Hz, 1H), 6.18 (dd, J = 16.8, 1.7 Hz, 1H), 5.71 (dd, J = 10.7, 1.7 Hz, 1H), 5.51 (dd, J = 11.8, 8.5 Hz, 1H), 3.88–3.68 (m, 6H), 3.58 (dd, J = 18.5, 8.0 Hz, 2H), 3.00 (s, 4H), 2.93 (s, 3H), 2.14–1.75 (m, 4H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, MeOD) δ 167.51, 163.22, 157.52, 157.08, 156.64, 148.21, 147.76, 135.54, 130.73, 129.57, 129.11, 128.33, 123.54, 121.78, 117.81, 115.39, 97.22, 71.94, 68.00, 51.70, 44.29, 40.54, 32.44, 31.55, 28.01. HRMS (m/z) calcd. for C29H34N9O3 ([M+H]+) 556.2785; found 556.2779.
Compounds 34–46 were synthesized with the same procedures as for 9.

The enzymatic activities against Itk, Btk, Jak3, and EGFR were tested with the HTRF® KinEASE™-STK kit (Cisbio Bioassays); activities of some inhibitors against Itk were evaluated using the LanthaScreen™ Eu Kinase Binding Assay. All protocols are available from Cisbio and Life Technologies [35].

Compounds were incubated with Itk over different time periods (0–20 min) before adding substrate/ATP mixture to initiate the kinase reaction. The durations of other assay steps were kept constant [36].

2 × 106 Jurkat cells were seeded into a 12-well plate and treated with compounds for 2 h, then 10 μL anti-CD3/CD28 beads were added to the cell plate to stimulate the cells and incubated for 30 min; the cells were then collected, washed with PBS twice and lysed with cell lysis buffer. Western blotting analyses were conducted after separation by SDS-PAGE electrophoresis to estimate the amounts of proteins.

Jurkat, H9, Molt-4, and CCRF-CEM cells were cultured in RPMI-1640 (Gibco) supplemented with 1% penicillin-streptomycin and 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS, Gibco). Cells were seeded onto 96-well plates (3000 cells/well), treated with compounds for 72 h, and analyzed using the CellTiter-Glo® luminescent cell viability assay (Promega).

Jurkat, Molt-4, or CCRF-CEM cells (2 × 106 each) were incubated with a small amount of DMSO or various concentrations of compound 9 in a CO2 incubator at 37 °C for 24 h. The cells were collected, washed with ice-cold PBS twice, then lysed with cell lysis buffer (Beyotime). After centrifugation at 14,000 g for 15 min, the supernatant was collected. Western blot analyses were conducted after separation by SDS-PAGE electrophoresis to determine the amounts of caspase-3 and PARP.

Human recombinant Itk (5 μg), compound 41 (50 μM), and PBS were combined in a 10 μL reaction system, and the mixture was incubated for 24 h. According to a filter-aided sample preparation (FASP) protocol, buffer exchange (to 50 mM of NH4HCO3), and chemical modification (reduction with 20 mM DTT and alkylation with 50 mM iodoacetamide) were performed in the upper chamber of 10-kDa ultrafiltration device. Then, 0.25 μg of trypsin (Thermo Scientific) was added to the mixture and incubated at 37 °C for 4 h, then the mixture was boiled for 3 min, followed by addition of 0.25 μg of chymotrypsin (Thermo Scientific) to the sample. This mixture was incubated at 37 °C overnight. The digests were desalted using a Ziptip desalting column (Pierce) and evaporated to dryness using a SpeedVac. The dried peptides were resuspended in 8 μL of ddH2O containing 0.1% formic acid, sonicated, and analyzed using a Thermo Orbitrap Fusion Lumos proteomic mass spectrometer. Data processing was performed using Proteome Discoverer 2.1 software (Thermo Scientific).

Human recombinant Itk (0.5 μg, Carna Biosciences) was preincubated with DMSO, compounds 9, 41, PRN694 or BMS509744 at 20 μM for 2 h at ambient temperature, then probe 46 was added to the mixture to a final concentration of 2 μM, and the mixture was incubated for 3 h. The mixture was then subjected to a “click” reaction with TAMRA azide (100 μM, Lumiprobe), CuSO4 (1.0 mM), THTPA (100 μM), and NaVc (100 μM) for 1 h at room temperature. The reaction was stopped by addition of loading buffer, and proteins were separated by 10% Tris SDS-PAGE and the gel was scanned using a Pharos FX™ Plus Molecular imager (Bio-Rad) or stained using a SilverQuest™ kit (Thermo Fisher Scientific).

Compounds BMS509744, 9, 41, and PRN694 were incubated with 3 × 106 Jurkat cells at 10 μM for 3 h, then probe 46 was added to the cells at 5 μM for another 3 h of incubation. The cells were lysed with lysis buffer (50 mM HEPES, pH 8.0, 150 mM NaCl, 0.1 mM EDTA, 0.1% Triton X-100 and complete protease inhibitors) and centrifuged at 14000 g for 15 min; the soluble fractions were subjected to a “click” reaction with Biotin-PEG-N3 (100 μM, Biomatrick Inc.), CuSO4 (1.0 mM), THTPA (100 μM) and NaVc (100 μM). The samples were precipitated with CH3OH (600 μL), CHCl3 (150 μL), and H2O (300 μL) sequentially and briefly vortexed. After centrifugation at 14,000 g for 3 min, the protein disk was washed twice with CH3OH (500 μL), air-dried and re-dissolved in 200 μL of the “click” buffer (50 mM HEPES, pH 8.0, 1% SDS) by sonication. 40 μL of streptavidin-sepharose (GE Healthcare) beads were added to each sample and incubated at 4 °C with continuous rotation overnight. The beads were washed with lysis buffer containing 4 M urea (1 mL) 4 times and then boiled in the presence of Laemmli sample buffer with 2-mercaptoethanol. The eluted proteins were immunoblotted with anti-Itk antibody.

Docking was performed with Molecular Operating Environment software (MOE, 2015). After the X-ray crystal structure (PDB code: 3qgw) was loaded into MOE, the preparation was conducted according to the MOE manual. After compound 11 was docked into the ATP-binding pocket with the default algorithm, the conformation with the highest scores were selected and visualized with PyMOL. Ligand was modified by the “Builder” to generate docking models of compounds 9 and 15.

Discovery of 1-{(3R,4R)-3-[({5-chloro-2-[(1-methyl-1H-pyrazol-4-yl)amino]-7H-pyrrolo[2,3-d]pyrimidin-4-yl}-oxy)methyl]-4-methoxypyrrolidin-1-yl}prop-2-en-1-one (PF-06459988), a potent, WT sparing, irreversible inhibitor of T790M-containing EGFR mutants
